elements.content: Four polyoxotungstate solid state structures comprising discrete and polymeric architectures based on CeIII complexes of monolacunary Wells-Dawson-type anions [α2-PV 2WVI 17O61]10–, isolated as [NMe4]7Li4K3[{Ce­(H2O)3­(α2-P2W17O61)}2]·35H2O (KLT-1), [NMe4]8Na2[Ce­(H2O)7]2­[{Ce­(CH3COO)­(H2O)4(α2-P2W17O61)}2]·32.5H2O (NT-2), [NMe4]8K0.5Na1.5[Ce­(H2O)7]2­[{Ce­(H2O)1.5(CH3COO)­(α2-P2W17O61)}2]·22H2O (KNT-3), and [NMe4]3Li­[Ce­(H2O)7]­[Ce­(H2O)4(α2-P2W17O61)]·15H2O (LT-4), illustrate the structural flexibility of CeIII ions, here imparted by their variable coordination numbers, with respect to their incorporation into polyoxometalate clusters versus their role in intercluster bridging in the solid state. While KLT-1 comprises discrete dimeric {CeP2W17}2 clusters, NT-2 and KNT-3 represent coordination polymers of linear {(Ce)­(CeP2W17)} n strands, every two of which are paired via acetate bridges to yield a ladder-like topology. Finally, LT-4 features the same {(Ce)­(CeP2W17)} n strands but in alternating orientation, enabling the formation of a 2D net. The title compounds have been isolated and fully characterized via single-crystal and powder X-ray diffraction, elemental and thermogravimetric analyses, IR spectroscopy, and SQUID magnetometry. The discrete polyanion [{Ce­(H2O)3(α2-P2W17O61)}2]14– (1) exhibits considerable stability in aqueous medium and interesting electrochemical behavior associated with redox transitions of its CeIII and WVI centers.

Finally, LT-4 features the same {(Ce)(CeP2W17)} n  strands but in alternating orientation, enabling the formation of a 2D net. The title compounds have been isolated and fully characterized via single-crystal and powder X-ray diffraction, elemental and thermogravimetric analyses, IR spectroscopy, and SQUID magnetometry. elements.content:
Ce­(III) ions unfold a surprising structural variety in binding to and linking lacunary Wells-Dawson-type polyoxotungstates, leading to “cap-to-belt”-bridged cluster pairs, 1D chains, and a 2D net.

Introduction

Lanthanide complexes of polyoxotungstates (POTs), i.e. polynuclear oxo complexes of WVI centers that can act as structurally rigid multidentate O donor ligands, have attracted significant attention over the past 20 years, motivated by the possibility to combine and enhance intrinsic features of both lanthanide and POT constituents within one molecular structure. Thus, large magnetic anisotropy of lanthanides arising from the unquenched orbital momentum and crystal field effects make their complexes highly attractive as potential nanoscale magnets; while POTs, in their turn, can provide robust inorganic matrices to stabilize unusual coordination geometries of LnIII ions within thermally and redox-stable species as well as protect the magnetic core from any interactions with neighboring molecules or with the electrode surfaces in molecular devices. Furthermore, a synergy of catalytic properties of POTs and LnIII was demonstrated to result in development of competitive catalytic systems for various chemical processes. The luminescent properties of Ln-POTs have also attracted considerable attention.

Ce(III) ions unfold a surprising structural variety in binding to and linking lacunary Wells-Dawson-type polyoxotungstates, leading to "cap-to-belt"-bridged cluster pairs, 1D chains, and a 2D net.

Introduction

Lanthanide complexes of polyoxotungstates (POTs), i.e. polynuclear oxo complexes of WVI centers that can act as structurally rigid multidentate O donor ligands, have attracted significant attention over the past 20 years, motivated by the possibility to combine and enhance intrinsic features of both lanthanide and POT constituents within one molecular structure. Furthermore, a synergy of catalytic properties of POTs and LnIII was demonstrated to result in development of competitive catalytic systems for various chemical processes. The luminescent properties of Ln-POTs have also attracted considerable attention.

elements.content: One of the most intensively studied members of the Ln/POT family is based on LnIII centers and [P2W17O61]10– ({P2W17}) polyanions. {P2W17} represents a monolacunary derivative of the archetypal Wells-Dawson-type phosphotungstate [α-P2W18O62]6– ({P2W18}), from which one [WO]4+ group has formally been removed. Two isomers of {P2W17} are known: in the {α1-P2W17} derivative the WO unit is absent from one of the two central {PW6} “belts” of the oval-shaped {P2W18} structure, while in the more stable {α2-P2W17} isomer the WO unit is removed from one of the two {W3} “caps” of the parent {P2W18} polyanion (Figure S1). The four oxygen atoms surrounding the thus-formed vacant (or lacunary) site in the POT structure can readily coordinate to various oxophilic heterometals including lanthanides. The known lanthanide complexes of {P2W17} can be categorized into three main classes: (1) sandwich-type [LnIII(P2W17O61)2]17– (and [CeIV(P2W17O61)2]16–) species with a 1:2 Ln:{P2W17} ratio; (2) discrete polyanions based on 1:1 {Ln­(H2O) n P2W17O61}7– units; and (3) coordination polymers based on LnIII/{P2W17} complexes.

Two isomers of {P2W17} are known: in the {α1-P2W17} derivative the WO unit is absent from one of the two central {PW6} "belts" of the oval-shaped {P2W18} structure, while in the more stable {α2-P2W17} isomer the WO unit is removed from one of the two {W3} "caps" of the parent {P2W18} polyanion (Figure S1). The four oxygen atoms surrounding the thus-formed vacant (or lacunary) site in the POT structure can readily coordinate to various oxophilic heterometals including lanthanides. The known lanthanide complexes of {P2W17} can be categorized into three main classes: (1) sandwich-type [LnIII(P2W17O61)2]17- (and [CeIV(P2W17O61)2]16-) species with a 1:2 Ln:{P2W17} ratio; (2) discrete polyanions based on 1:1 {Ln(H2O) n P2W17O61}7- units; and (3) coordination polymers based on LnIII/{P2W17} complexes.

elements.content: The first reported 1:2 type species, [CeIII(α2-P2W17O61)2]17– and [CeIV(α2-P2W17O61)2]16–, the formation and composition of which was conjectured based on spectroscopic and elemental analysis already in 1971, was followed in 1979 by X-ray diffraction-based characterization of K16[CeIV(α2-P2W17O61)2]·50H2O. Since then considerable work was done to identify 1:2 derivatives based on other LnIII ions as well as to prepare the {α1-P2W17}-based analogues and investigate spectroscopic and electrochromic properties of such polyanions. It was recently shown that [LnIII(α2-P2W17O61)2]17– polyanions can also exist in a trans configuration that varies from the cis in the mutual orientation of the two {α2-P2W17} ligands. The chirality of the [cis-LnIII(α2-P2W17O61)2]16– structures arising from the 45° rotation of the {α2-P2W17} units relative to each other around the antiprismatically coordinated Ln centers was also investigated, and it was found that enantiomerically pure polyanions can be isolated by cocrystallization with d- or l-proline.

elements.content: The existence of 1:1 monomeric Ln derivatives of both [(H2O) n LnIII(α1-P2W17O61)]7– ({α1-LnP2W17}) and [(H2O) n LnIII(α2-P2W17O61)2]7– ({α2-LnP2W17}) isomers has been confirmed in aqueous and organic solutions via 31P and 183W NMR as well as ESI MS techniques; however, a crystal structure for the monomeric form was reported only for [(H2O)4LuIII(α1-P2W17O61)]7–. Other attempts to crystallize 1:1 complexes without organic coligands led to isolation of dimeric 2:2 or cyclic trimeric 3:3 structures, where the LnIII ion of the {(H2O) n LnIII(α1/2-P2W17O61)} monomer binds to four oxygen atoms of the vacant site of the {P2W17} unit, to terminal aqua ligands as well as to a single terminal O center of a neighboring {(H2O) n LnIII(α1/2-P2W17O61)} moiety; this O site can belong either to the WVI from the {PW6} “belt” or to the WVI from the {LnW2} or {W3} “cap” of the {P2W17} unit. Other types of oligomerized 1:1 units comprise either acetate bridging ligands, as observed in the only dimeric derivative [{La­(CH3COO)­(H2O)2(α2-P2W17O61)}2]16–, or an oxalate bridge (ox2–), as reported for [Ln2(H2ox)2(ox)­(α2-P2W17O61)2]8– (Ln = HoIII, ErIII, TmIII, YbIII as well as YIII) and [{Yb­(α2-P2W17O61)}4(ox)3(H2O)4]34– polyanions. Recently it was also shown that picolinic acid (Hpic) can stabilize 1:1 {α2-LnP2W17} species within the hybrid [Ln­(Hpic)2(α2-P2W17O61)]7– polyanions decorated with an additional [Ln­(H2O)­(Hpic)3]3+ cation (Ln = GdIII, TbIII, DyIII, HoIII, ErIII, TmIII, YbIII and YIII). In the other known hybrid, [{Ce­(η1-C6H5NO2)2(H2O)6[Ce­(H2O)3(α2-P2W17O61)]}2{Ce­(η2-C6H5NO2)2(H2O)5[Ce­(H2O)­(α2-P2W17O61)]}2]24–, isonicotinate groups help to stabilize a discrete tetramer built by the above-mentioned 2:2 dimer of {α2-LnP2W17} units each of which is decorated by an additional {α2-LnP2W17} moiety as well as CeIII centers with coordinated isonicotinate and aqua ligands.

elements.content: Two types of LnIII/{P2W17}-based (Ln = Nd and Eu) coordination polymers have been reported. In the first one, a 1D structure, dimers of {α2-LnIIIP2W17} moieties are interconnected into infinite chains by additional LnIII ions. In the second one, external LnIII centers link chains composed of interconnected {α2-LnIIIP2W17} units into 2D layers.
elements.clean_text: Two types of LnIII/{P2W17}-based (Ln = Nd and Eu) coordination polymers have been reported. In the first one, a 1D structure, dimers of {α2-LnIIIP2W17} moieties are interconnected into infinite chains by additional LnIII ions. In the second one, external LnIII centers link chains composed of interconnected {α2-LnIIIP2W17} units into 2D layers.

elements.content: Herein we report three novel architectures composed of CeIII ions and {α2-P2W17} units, isolated as [NMe4]7Li4K3[{Ce­(H2O)3­(α2-P2W17O61)}2]·35H2O (KLT-1), [NMe4]8Na2[Ce­(H2O)7]2­[{Ce­(CH3COO)­(H2O)4(α2-P2W17O61)}2]·32.5H2O (NT-2), K0.5Na1.5[NMe4]8[Ce­(H2O)7]2­[{Ce­(H2O)1.5(CH3COO)­(α2-P2W17O61)}2]·22H2O (KNT-3), and Li­[NMe4]3[Ce­(H2O)7]­[Ce­(H2O)4(α2-P2W17O61)]·15H2O (LT-4). All compounds form at different pH values (2.5–6) from multilacunary derivatives of {P2W18} as POT precursors (Figure S2): Whereas KLT-1 and KNT-3 are derived from [α-H2P2W12O48]12–, NT-2 and LT-4 are prepared starting from [α-P2W15O56]12–. KLT-1 comprises the discrete [{Ce­(H2O)3(α2-P2W17O61)}2]14– polyanion (1) representing the first CeIII-based 2:2 dimer with a so-called “cap-to-belt” bridging motif built, which in 1 is not decorated by any additional CeIII centers. Compounds NT-2 and KNT-3 are based on thus-far unknown [{Ce­(H2O) x (CH3COO)­(α2-P2W17O61)}2]16– polyanions connected by additional CeIII centers into 1D coordination polymers, {[Ce­(H2O)7]2[{Ce­(H2O) x (CH3COO)­(α2-P2W17O61)}2]} n (x = 2 in 2 and 1.5 in 3); while in LT-4 the external CeIII sites provides a connection of the chain-like {Ce­(H2O)4(α2-P2W17O61)} n moieties into unique 2D nets of composition {[Ce­(H2O)7]­[Ce­(H2O)4(α2-P2W17O61)]} m 4m– (4).

elements.content: The precursor compounds Na12[α-P2W15O56]·24H2O and K12[α-H2P2W12O48]·24H2O, as well as K10[α2-P2W17O61]·20H2O (used for diamagnetic corrections) were prepared as previously reported, and their identities were confirmed by IR spectroscopy. All other reagents were of analytical grade and were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Starting Materials

The precursor compounds Na12[α-P2W15O56]⋅24H2O and K12[α-H2P2W12O48]⋅24H2O, as well as K10[α2-P2W17O61]⋅20H2O (used for diamagnetic corrections) were prepared as previously reported, and their identities were confirmed by IR spectroscopy. All other reagents were of analytical grade and were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification.

elements.content: Elemental analyses (inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) and C, H, and N) were obtained from the Central Institute for Engineering, Electronics and Analytics (ZEA-3), Forschungszentrum Jülich GmbH (Jülich, Germany). Thermogravimetric/differential thermal analysis (TGA/DTA) measurements were carried out with a Mettler Toledo SDTA 851 in a dry N2 flux (60 mL min–1) at a heating rate of 5 K min–1. FT-IR spectra were recorded on Bruker Vertex 70 and Avatar 360 spectrometers using KBr pellets.
elements.clean_text:
Instruments

Elemental analyses (inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) and C, H, and N) were obtained from the Central Institute for Engineering, Electronics and Analytics (ZEA-3), Forschungszentrum Jülich GmbH (Jülich, Germany). Thermogravimetric/differential thermal analysis (TGA/DTA) measurements were carried out with a Mettler Toledo SDTA 851 in a dry N2 flux (60 mL min-1) at a heating rate of 5 K min-1. FT-IR spectra were recorded on Bruker Vertex 70 and Avatar 360 spectrometers using KBr pellets.

elements.content: Cyclic voltammograms were recorded on a 0.5 mM solution of KLT-1 in 0.66 M LiOAc buffer (pH 5.3) using a SP-150 potentiostat (Bio Logic Science Instruments) controlled by EC-Lab software. The conventional three-electrode electrochemical cell included a glassy carbon working electrode with the diameter of 3 mm, a platinum wire counter electrode, and an aqueous Ag/AgCl (3 M NaCl) reference electrode (0.196 V vs SHE determined by measuring [Fe­(CN)6]3/4– as an internal standard). The solutions were thoroughly deaerated with pure argon and kept under a positive Ar pressure during the experiments. Alumina powder was used for the cleaning of the working electrode which was then thoroughly rinsed with deionized water. Redox potentials were defined from the average values of the anodic and cathodic peak potentials and reported vs the Ag/AgCl reference electrode.

The solutions were thoroughly deaerated with pure argon and kept under a positive Ar pressure during the experiments. Alumina powder was used for the cleaning of the working electrode which was then thoroughly rinsed with deionized water. Redox potentials were defined from the average values of the anodic and cathodic peak potentials and reported vs the Ag/AgCl reference electrode.

elements.content: Magnetic data of the potassium precursor (K10[α2-P2W17O61]·20H2O for diamagnetic correction purposes), KLT-1, KNT-3, and LT-4 were recorded using a Quantum Design MPMS-5XL SQUID magnetometer. Polycrystalline samples were compacted and immobilized into cylindrical PTFE capsules. The data were acquired as a function of the magnetic field (0.1–5.0 T at 2.0 K) and temperature (2.0–290 K at 0.1 T). Data were corrected for the diamagnetic contributions of the sample holders and compounds (χm,dia = −3.145 × 10–4 cm3/mol ([α2-P2W17O61]10–), using Pascal’s constants: χm,dia/10–3 cm3/mol = −1.62 (KLT-1), −1.53 (KNT-3), −0.850 (LT-4)).

Polycrystalline samples were compacted and immobilized into cylindrical PTFE capsules. The data were acquired as a function of the magnetic field (0.1-5.0 T at 2.0 K) and temperature (2.0-290 K at 0.1 T). elements.content: Samples of K12[α-H2P2W12O48]·24H2O (394 mg, 0.10 mmol), CeCl3·7H2O (186.5 mg, 0.50 mmol), and phenyl phosphonic acid (39 mg, 0.25 mmol) were dissolved in aqueous 1 M LiCl medium (20 mL), and the pH of the resulting solution was adjusted to 6 by 1 M NaOHaq. The reaction mixture was then heated at 70 °C for 4 days followed by addition of tetramethylammonium chloride (110 mg, 1.0 mmol) under vigorous stirring. After cooling to room temperature, the reaction mixture was filtered and the obtained orange solution was left for evaporation. Orange prismatic crystals of KLT-1 were collected after 2 weeks. Yield: 332 mg (94.0% based on W). Elemental analysis, mass %, calculated for C28H166Ce2K3Li4N7O163P4W34 (found): C, 3.36 (3.34); H, 1.67 (1.65); Ce, 2.80 (2.91); K, 1.17 (1.05); N, 0.98 (0.97); P, 1.24 (1.22). FT-IR (2% KBr pellet), νmax/cm–1: 3420 (s, br); 1623 (m); 1483 (m); 1448 (w); 1415 (w); 1383 (m); 1088 (w); 1055 (m); 1017 (s); 943 (s); 911(s); 785 (s); 691 (s); 524 (s); 455(s).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [NMe4]7Li4K3[{Ce(H2O)3(α2-P2W17O61)}2]⋅35H2O (KLT-1)

Samples of K12[α-H2P2W12O48]⋅24H2O (394 mg, 0.10 mmol), CeCl3⋅7H2O (186.5 mg, 0.50 mmol), and phenyl phosphonic acid (39 mg, 0.25 mmol) were dissolved in aqueous 1 M LiCl medium (20 mL), and the pH of the resulting solution was adjusted to 6 by 1 M NaOHaq. The reaction mixture was then heated at 70 °C for 4 days followed by addition of tetramethylammonium chloride (110 mg, 1.0 mmol) under vigorous stirring. After cooling to room temperature, the reaction mixture was filtered and the obtained orange solution was left for evaporation. Orange prismatic crystals of KLT-1 were collected after 2 weeks. Yield: 332 mg (94.0% based on W). Elemental analysis, mass %, calculated for C28H166Ce2K3Li4N7O163P4W34 (found): C, 3.36 (3.34); H, 1.67 (1.65); Ce, 2.80 (2.91); K, 1.17 (1.05); N, 0.98 (0.97); P, 1.24 (1.22). The reaction mixture (pH 2.5) was heated at 70 °C for 24 h and then tetramethylammonium chloride (110 mg, 1.0 mmol) was added under vigorous stirring. After cooling to room temperature, the reaction mixture was filtered and the obtained orange solution was left for evaporation. Orange prismatic crystals of LT-4 were collected after 1 week. Yield: 325 mg (71.6% based on W). Elemental analysis, mass %, calculated for C12H88Ce2LiN3O87P2W17 (found): C, 2.80 (2.76); H, 1.73 (1.5); Ce, 5.45 (5.78); N, 0.82 (0.83); P, 1.20 (1.18). FT-IR spectrum (2% KBr pellet), νmax/cm-1: 3420 (s, br); 1616 (m); 1483 (m); 1447 (w); 1415 (w); 1090 (m); 1058 (w); 1017 (m); 945 (s); 908 (s); 795 (s); 708 (s); 525 (s); 458 (s); 422 (s).

elements.content: Data were collected at 100 K on a STOE STADIVARI diffractometer for KLT-1 and on a Bruker APEX II CCD diffractometer for NT-2, KNT-3, and LT-4 with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The crystals were mounted in a Hampton cryoloop with Paratone-N oil to prevent water loss. Absorption corrections for KLT-1 were done by Gaussian integration using STOE X-Red32 software, and afterward, scaling of reflection intensities was performed within STOE LANA. For the other structures (NT-2, KNT-3, and LT-4), absorption corrections were applied empirically using the SADABS program.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Single-Crystal Diffraction Data

Data were collected at 100 K on a STOE STADIVARI diffractometer for KLT-1 and on a Bruker APEX II CCD diffractometer for NT-2, KNT-3, and LT-4 with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The crystals were mounted in a Hampton cryoloop with Paratone-N oil to prevent water loss. Absorption corrections for KLT-1 were done by Gaussian integration using STOE X-Red32 software, and afterward, scaling of reflection intensities was performed within STOE LANA. For the other structures (NT-2, KNT-3, and LT-4), absorption corrections were applied empirically using the SADABS program.

elements.content: The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares method against |F|2 with anisotropic thermal parameters for all heavy atoms (Ce, P, W, and K) employing the SHELXTL software package. Hydrogen atoms of water molecules and Li+ counterions (KLT-1, LT-4) were not located. Hydrogens of acetate ions in NT-2 and KNT-3 were placed in geometrically calculated positions.
elements.clean_text: The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares method against |F|2 with anisotropic thermal parameters for all heavy atoms (Ce, P, W, and K) employing the SHELXTL software package. Hydrogen atoms of water molecules and Li+ counterions (KLT-1, LT-4) were not located. Hydrogens of acetate ions in NT-2 and KNT-3 were placed in geometrically calculated positions.

elements.content: The relative site occupancy factors for the disordered positions of O atoms of solvent water molecules, potassium, sodium, and TMA+ counterions were either first refined in an isotropic approximation with U iso= 0.05 and then fixed at the obtained values and refined without the thermal parameters restrictions, or refined using a combination of PART and EADP commands.
elements.clean_text: The relative site occupancy factors for the disordered positions of O atoms of solvent water molecules, potassium, sodium, and TMA+ counterions were either first refined in an isotropic approximation with U iso= 0.05 and then fixed at the obtained values and refined without the thermal parameters restrictions, or refined using a combination of PART and EADP commands.

elements.content: Due to severe disorder we were not able to locate part of solvent H2O molecules as well as part of disordered TMA+ counterions in the structures of KLT-1 and LT-4, which is a typical problem in polyoxotungstate crystallography. Thus, only 5.5 out 7 (KLT-1) and 2.5 out 3 (LT-4) TMA+ cations and 19 out of 35 (KLT-1) and 11 out of 15 (LT-4) solvent H2O molecules found by elemental and thermogravimetric analyses could be located from XRD data. Nevertheless, in the final formula we used the composition determined for the bulk material by combination of several analytical techniques for overall consistency (as also this bulk material will be used for all further studies).
elements.clean_text: Due to severe disorder we were not able to locate part of solvent H2O molecules as well as part of disordered TMA+ counterions in the structures of KLT-1 and LT-4, which is a typical problem in polyoxotungstate crystallography. Thus, only 5.5 out 7 (KLT-1) and 2.5 out 3 (LT-4) TMA+ cations and 19 out of 35 (KLT-1) and 11 out of 15 (LT-4) solvent H2O molecules found by elemental and thermogravimetric analyses could be located from XRD data. Nevertheless, in the final formula we used the composition determined for the bulk material by combination of several analytical techniques for overall consistency (as also this bulk material will be used for all further studies).

elements.content:
The relatively high residual electron density peaks in the structures (3.0–4.5 e Å–3) are located in the proximity of the W centers and should correspond to some residual absorption artifacts.

Additional crystallographic data are summarized in and . Further details on the crystal structures investigation can be obtained, free of charge, on application to CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK: http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/, e-mail: data_request@ccdc.cam.ac.uk, or fax: + 441223 336033 upon quoting 1898282 (KLT-1), 1898284 (NT-2), 1898283 (KNT-3), and 1898285 (LT-4) numbers.

Data (Figure S14–S17) were recorded with a powder diffractometer (STOE STADI P). The experiments were performed on flat samples in a transmission geometry using a Cu anode (Kα1, λ = 1.54059 Å; 40 kV, 30 mA) and a focusing Ge-monochromator (Johann type) at room temperature The omega angle was held at 55° and the data were recorded with an image plate detector (140° in 2Θ, step width 0.015°). The exposure times were between 3600 and 7200 s.
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction (PXRD) Patterns

Data (Figure S14-S17) were recorded with a powder diffractometer (STOE STADI P). The experiments were performed on flat samples in a transmission geometry using a Cu anode (Kα1, λ = 1.54059 Å; 40 kV, 30 mA) and a focusing Ge-monochromator (Johann type) at room temperature The omega angle was held at 55° and the data were recorded with an image plate detector (140° in 2Θ, step width 0.015°). The exposure times were between 3600 and 7200 s.

elements.content: For the measurements the crystals were mortared in the mother liquor to prevent the removal of cocrystallized solvent molecules and a consequent crystallinity loss and placed to a sample holder together with a small amount of mother liquid. We observed that the degree of mortaring (the random orientation of crystallites in the sample holder) plays a crucial role for the quality of the obtained XRD patterns.
elements.clean_text: For the measurements the crystals were mortared in the mother liquor to prevent the removal of cocrystallized solvent molecules and a consequent crystallinity loss and placed to a sample holder together with a small amount of mother liquid. We observed that the degree of mortaring (the random orientation of crystallites in the sample holder) plays a crucial role for the quality of the obtained XRD patterns.

elements.content: The polyanion structures 1– 4 were obtained by reactions of CeCl3·7H2O with either [α-P2W15O56]12– or [α-P2W12O48]14– polyanions in mildly acidic aqueous media (pH 2.5 (1), 4.8 (2 and 3), and 6.0 (4)) at 70 °C (see Figure S2) and crystallized as hydrated mixed alkali metal/tetramethylammonium (TMA+) salts. Both POT precursors, trilacunary [α-P2W15O56]12– and hexalacunary [α-P2W12O48]14– derivatives of the Wells-Dawson-type phosphotungstate [α-P2W18O62]6–, are not stable in aqueous solutions and in reactions with CeIII under the used conditions transform into the architectures based on the more stable monolacunary Wells-Dawson-type derivative [α2-P2W17O61]10–. This type of rearrangement is not unusual and was already observed several times during the synthesis of the previously reported LnIII complexes of {α2-P2W17}; however it is interesting to note that such transformation occurs in a rather wide pH range, from 2.5 to 6.0. Phenylphosphonic acid, PhPO3H2, was initially added to the reaction mixtures for preparation of 1–4 as a potential coligand to the POT precursors; however, it did not participate directly in formation of the complexes. Nevertheless, the compounds could not be isolated in the absence of PhPO3H2 despite keeping exactly the same pH values for the reaction solutions.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Crystal Structures

The polyanion structures 1- 4 were obtained by reactions of CeCl3⋅7H2O with either [α-P2W15O56]12- or [α-P2W12O48]14- polyanions in mildly acidic aqueous media (pH 2.5 (1), 4.8 (2 and 3), and 6.0 (4)) at 70 °C (see Figure S2) and crystallized as hydrated mixed alkali metal/tetramethylammonium (TMA+) salts. Both POT precursors, trilacunary [α-P2W15O56]12- and hexalacunary [α-P2W12O48]14- derivatives of the Wells-Dawson-type phosphotungstate [α-P2W18O62]6-, are not stable in aqueous solutions and in reactions with CeIII under the used conditions transform into the architectures based on the more stable monolacunary Wells-Dawson-type derivative [α2-P2W17O61]10-. This type of rearrangement is not unusual and was already observed several times during the synthesis of the previously reported LnIII complexes of {α2-P2W17}; however it is interesting to note that such transformation occurs in a rather wide pH range, from 2.5 to 6.0. Phenylphosphonic acid, PhPO3H2, was initially added to the reaction mixtures for preparation of 1-4 as a potential coligand to the POT precursors; however, it did not participate directly in formation of the complexes. Nevertheless, the compounds could not be isolated in the absence of PhPO3H2 despite keeping exactly the same pH values for the reaction solutions.

elements.content: The structures of KLT-1, NT-2, KNT-3, and LT-4 are all based on similar {(H2O) n CeIII(α2-P2W17O61)}7–­({α2-CeP2W17}) units that are interconnected to each other in different modes, resulting in a discrete (for 1) or polymeric (1D chains for 2 and 3 and a 2D net for 4) architecture. The {α2-CeP2W17} unit is composed of a monolacunary Wells-Dawson type phosphotungstate {α2-P2W17} coordinating a CeIII ion in its vacant site. The structure of {α2-P2W17} comprises two central tetrahedral phosphate groups surrounded by 17 WVI centers in octahedral coordination geometry, which are arranged in one complete {W3} “cap”, two central {PW6} “belts”, and one deficient {W2} “cap” missing a WVI ion and thus offering nucleophilic O atoms which can be coordinated by a heterometal (Figure S1). The 8- or 9-coordinate CeIII ion in {α2-CeP2W17} binds to four O atoms of the {α2-P2W17} moiety, the remaining 4 or 5 coordination sites are occupied either by terminal water ligands or by an O atom of an adjacent {α2-CeP2W17} fragment (1, 4) or oxygens of acetate ligands (2, 3).
elements.clean_text: The structures of KLT-1, NT-2, KNT-3, and LT-4 are all based on similar {(H2O) n CeIII(α2-P2W17O61)}7-({α2-CeP2W17}) units that are interconnected to each other in different modes, resulting in a discrete (for 1) or polymeric (1D chains for 2 and 3 and a 2D net for 4) architecture. The {α2-CeP2W17} unit is composed of a monolacunary Wells-Dawson type phosphotungstate {α2-P2W17} coordinating a CeIII ion in its vacant site. The structure of {α2-P2W17} comprises two central tetrahedral phosphate groups surrounded by 17 WVI centers in octahedral coordination geometry, which are arranged in one complete {W3} "cap", two central {PW6} "belts", and one deficient {W2} "cap" missing a WVI ion and thus offering nucleophilic O atoms which can be coordinated by a heterometal (Figure S1). The 8- or 9-coordinate CeIII ion in {α2-CeP2W17} binds to four O atoms of the {α2-P2W17} moiety, the remaining 4 or 5 coordination sites are occupied either by terminal water ligands or by an O atom of an adjacent {α2-CeP2W17} fragment (1, 4) or oxygens of acetate ligands (2, 3).

elements.content: In 1, the two {α2-CeP2W17} units form a discrete centrosymmetric dimer, where the CeIII center of one {α2-CeP2W17} moiety binds an O atom from the “belt” part of the neighboring {α2-CeP2W17} unit. In addition to four O atoms of {α2-P2W17} (Ce–O 2.365(10)–2.449(12) Å) and an O atom of the second {α2-CeP2W17} unit (Ce–O 2.481(11) Å) every CeIII center coordinates three terminal aqua ligands (Ce–O 2.533(11)–2.546(13) Å) and, thus, is 8-coordinate and exhibits a square-antiprismatic coordination environment (). Such kind of “cap-to-belt” or “side-on” dimeric structure typically forms for mid-to-late (i.e., smaller) lanthanide ions for which the coordination number of 8 is characteristic as it was previously observed for NdIII, EuIII, and LuIII as well as for YIII. Larger lanthanide ions, such as LaIII, CeIII, and PrIII, instead, have a tendency to form so-called “cap-to-cap” or “head-on” dimers where each LnIII center binds a {α2-P2W17} polyanion, four terminal aqua-ligands as well as an O atom of the second {α2-CeP2W17} unit located in its incomplete {W2Ln} “cap” and is 9-coordinate. It was even initially proposed that “cap-to-belt” dimeric structures do not exist for these large lanthanide ions. However, in 2007 [{Ce­(H2O)8}2­{(H2O)4Ce­(α2-P2W17O61)}2]8– polyanions were reported, in which the “cap-to-belt” dimers based on nine-coordinated CeIII ions are decorated with two {CeIII(H2O)8} groups attached on the periphery of the {W2Ce} caps. Thus, it appears that a Ce coordination number greater than 8 does not prevent the formation of “cap-to-belt” dimers, although in the case of 1 all CeIII ions are 8-coordinate. These literature-reported polyanions were obtained by hydrolysis of the intact Wells-Dawson-type phosphotungstate [α-P2W18O32]6– in the presence of cerium­(III) chloride. Similar species were also isolated for NdIII, where, however, all NdIII are 8-coordinated. A significant advantage of 1 in comparison to the reported [{Ce­(H2O)8}2­{(H2O)4Ce­(α2-P2W17O61)}2]8– polyanions is the absence of any additional CeIII ions that are only loosely coordinated to oxygen positions of the polyoxotungstate surface, which allows for unambiguous characterization of the dimeric species in solution by UV–vis spectroscopy or cyclic voltammetry (vide infra).

elements.content: Assemblies 2 and 3, shown in and , exhibit similar structures based on 2:2 dimers of {α2-CeP2W17} units interconnected by two acetate groups into the entities with the general formula [{Ce­(CH3COO)­(H2O) x ­(α2-P2W17O61)}2]16– (where x = 2 (NT-2) or 1.5 (KNT-3)). Every CeIII ion within the dimeric entity coordinates four O atoms of the POT (Ce–O 2.450(9)–2.486(9) Å (NT-2) and 2.437(17)–2.465(16) (KNT-3)), both oxygens of one of the acetate ligands (Ce–O 2.578(10) and 2.642(9) Å (NT-2); 2.60(2) and 2.641(16) Å (KNT-3)), and one O atom of the second acetate ligand (Ce–O 2.562(9) Å (NT-2), 2.537(16) Å (KNT-3)) as well as terminal aqua ligands (2.582(12)–2.605(10) (NT-2) and 2.58(3)–2.62(2) Å (KNT-3)). The only difference between structures of 2 and 3 is the number of the terminal aqua-ligands coordinated to the CeIII ions in [{Ce­(CH3COO)­(H2O) x ­(α2-P2W17O61)}2]16– dimers, x. In the structure of 2, x = 2, and thus every CeIII ion appears to be nine-coordinated in a monocapped square-antiprismatic fashion. In 3, the site occupancy factor of one of these two aqua ligands refines to 0.5, and thus, x = 1.5, which means that the half of the CeIII ions are nine-coordinate while the second half of them have CN = 8 and exhibit a bicapped trigonal prismatic coordination environment. While such a type of connection of the monomeric units through the acetate bridges is commonly observed for the dimers based on monosubstituted Keggin-type ions [{Ln­(CH3COO)­(H2O) x (XW11O39)}2] Z−, only one dimer built by {α2-LnP2W17} moieties, [{La­(CH3COO)­(H2O)2­(α2-P2W17O61)}2]16–, is known. In 2 and 3 [{Ce­(CH3COO)­(H2O) x ­(α2-P2W17O61)}2]16– dimers are further linked into 1D chains via additional CeIII ions, each of which has CN 9 and binds oxygen atoms of the neighboring dimers (one from each, Ce–O: 2.501(9)–2.590(9) Å (NT-2) and 2.491(18)–2.590(16) Å (KNT-3)) as well as seven terminal aqua ligands (Ce–O 2.496(10)–2.587(10) Å (NT-2) and 2.494(18)–2.571(18) Å (KNT-3)); see and .

In the structure of 2, x = 2, and thus every CeIII ion appears to be nine-coordinated in a monocapped square-antiprismatic fashion. In 3, the site occupancy factor of one of these two aqua ligands refines to 0.5, and thus, x = 1.5, which means that the half of the CeIII ions are nine-coordinate while the second half of them have CN = 8 and exhibit a bicapped trigonal prismatic coordination environment. While such a type of connection of the monomeric units through the acetate bridges is commonly observed for the dimers based on monosubstituted Keggin-type ions [{Ln(CH3COO)(H2O) x (XW11O39)}2] Z-, only one dimer built by {α2-LnP2W17} moieties, [{La(CH3COO)(H2O)2(α2-P2W17O61)}2]16-, is known. In 2 and 3 [{Ce(CH3COO)(H2O) x (α2-P2W17O61)}2]16- dimers are further linked into 1D chains via additional CeIII ions, each of which has CN 9 and binds oxygen atoms of the neighboring dimers (one from each, Ce-O: 2.501(9)-2.590(9) Å (NT-2) and 2.491(18)-2.590(16) Å (KNT-3)) as well as seven terminal aqua ligands (Ce-O 2.496(10)-2.587(10) Å (NT-2) and 2.494(18)-2.571(18) Å (KNT-3)); see  and .

elements.content: It should be noted that both compounds, NT-2 and KNT-3, were obtained using similar reaction conditions but starting from different POT precursors, Na12[α-P2W15O56]·24H2O or K12[α-H2P2W12O48]·24H2O, respectively. This shows that complex equilibria exist in aqueous solutions of lacunary derivatives of Wells-Dawson phosphotungstates, that the type of the medium and final pH of the reaction mixture plays a much more important role than the type of precursor used, and that the lanthanide ions cannot provide sufficient stabilization for the initial POT precursor at the studied conditions.
elements.clean_text: It should be noted that both compounds, NT-2 and KNT-3, were obtained using similar reaction conditions but starting from different POT precursors, Na12[α-P2W15O56]⋅24H2O or K12[α-H2P2W12O48]⋅24H2O, respectively. This shows that complex equilibria exist in aqueous solutions of lacunary derivatives of Wells-Dawson phosphotungstates, that the type of the medium and final pH of the reaction mixture plays a much more important role than the type of precursor used, and that the lanthanide ions cannot provide sufficient stabilization for the initial POT precursor at the studied conditions.

elements.content: As illustrated in and , 4 represents a 2D coordination polymer constructed from {α2-CeP2W17} monomeric units and CeIII ions. The CeIII center in the each {α2-CeP2W17} subunit adopts a tricapped trigonal prismatic coordination environment and next to the oxygen atoms of the {α2-P2W17} phosphotungstate (Ce–O 2.469(18)–2.490(16) Å), binds four terminal water molecules (Ce–O 2.53(3)–2.66(2) Å) as well as an O atom of the {W3} groups of the neighboring {α2-CeP2W17} species (Ce–O 2.593(18) Å). This results in {(H2O)4Ce­(α2-CeP2W17O61)} n chains that propagate along the crystallographic b axis. These chains are further linked 2D nets by {CeIII(H2O)7} groups. The additional CeIII cations are not incorporated into the POT structure, but each of them binds a terminal O atom on the WVI center of the {W2Ce} “cap” of one {α2-CeP2W17} unit (Ce–O 2.56(2) Å), a terminal O atom on the WVI center in the {PW6} “belt” of the neighboring {α2-CeP2W17} unit (Ce–O 2.486(18) Å) as well as seven aqua ligands (Ce–O 2.49(3)–2.57(2) Å) in a tricapped trigonal prismatic coordination geometry. Interestingly, the type of connection between the external {CeIII(H2O)7} groups and {α2-CeP2W17} units in 4 and 2 and 3 is exactly the same despite pronounced differences of these structures (–).

elements.content: The FT-IR spectra of KLT-1, NT-2, KNT-3, and LT-4 (Figure S3) are nearly identical and show features characteristic for the LnIII complexes of {α2-P2W17}. All spectra exhibit three bands corresponding to P–O vibrations of the POT skeleton at around 1088, 1056, and 1016 cm–1, which compare well to the corresponding bands at 1084, 1049, and 1014 cm–1 in the spectrum of K10[α2-P2W17O61]·20H2O (Figure S3). The two peaks at around 939–948 and 910 cm–1 in these spectra are attributed to vibrations of the terminal WO bonds and could be compared with the peaks at 938 and 915 cm–1 in the spectrum of K10[α2-P2W17O61]·20H2O. The most pronounced difference in the spectra of the KLT-1, NT-2, KNT-3, LT-4, and K10[α2-P2W17O61]·20H2O appears in the region from 890 to 680 cm–1, where the peak at 885 cm–1 characteristic for K10[α2-P2W17O61]·20H2O is no more visible in the spectra of the cerium complexes, while the bands at 811 and 727 cm–1 are shifted to 797–785 and 710–691 cm–1, respectively; this reflects coordination of the polyoxotungstate by CeIII ions 1–4. These bands, as well as the weak bands in the 700–400 cm–1 area (with the strongest at 525 cm–1), correspond to W–O–W, W–O–P, and W–O–Ce vibrations. The two bands at 1628 and 1525–1542 cm–1 in the spectra of NT-2 and KNT-3 indicate the carboxylate groups of acetate ligands in these compounds. The broad band at around 3420–3445 cm–1 and the strong peak at 1616–1629 cm–1 in all spectra reflect stretching and bending vibrations of lattice and coordinated water molecules, respectively. A set of peaks featuring stretching and bending vibrations of C–N and C–H bonds in the TMA+ countercations appear at 1482, 1450, 1415, and 1385 cm–1.

elements.content: The thermal decomposition processes for KLT-1, NT-2, KNT-3, and LT-4 were investigated under an N2 atmosphere from room temperature (RT) to 900 °C (Figures S4–S7). For all compounds, thermal decomposition occurs in several steps, first of which starts already at RT and is completed at around 250 °C and corresponds to the removal of both lattice and (at higher temperatures) coordinated water molecules (see for a comparison of calculated and observed mass percent values). In the case of KNT-3 this step can be divided to two overlapping steps (Figure S6) indicating that some water molecules in the lattice are bound weaker than others. The next mass loss step(s) (250–650 °C) can be related to the decomposition of the tetramethylammonium cations (occurring via release of trimethylamine and other products, e.g. Me2O) and, in the case of NT-2 and KNT-3, acetate groups (decomposing under release of acetone and CO2). The processes at higher temperature correspond to the decomposition of the POT skeleton and formation of metal oxides.
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis

The thermal decomposition processes for KLT-1, NT-2, KNT-3, and LT-4 were investigated under an N2 atmosphere from room temperature (RT) to 900 °C (Figures S4-S7). For all compounds, thermal decomposition occurs in several steps, first of which starts already at RT and is completed at around 250 °C and corresponds to the removal of both lattice and (at higher temperatures) coordinated water molecules (see  for a comparison of calculated and observed mass percent values). In the case of KNT-3 this step can be divided to two overlapping steps (Figure S6) indicating that some water molecules in the lattice are bound weaker than others. The next mass loss step(s) (250-650 °C) can be related to the decomposition of the tetramethylammonium cations (occurring via release of trimethylamine and other products, e.g. Me2O) and, in the case of NT-2 and KNT-3, acetate groups (decomposing under release of acetone and CO2). The processes at higher temperature correspond to the decomposition of the POT skeleton and formation of metal oxides.

elements.content:
Solution studies (UV–vis spectroscopy and cyclic voltammetry) have been performed for the compound KLT-1 comprising a discrete cluster structure.

UV–vis Measurements

The UV–vis spectrum of KLT-1 redissolved in 0.66 M LiOAc buffer (pH 5.3) averaged from the solutions with concentrations between 4.0 × 10–6 and 8.0 × 10–6 M exhibits a sharp absorption maximum at 226 nm (ε = 140239 M–1 cm–1) and a shoulder at 275 nm (ε = 76684 M–1 cm–1) in the UV range () which are associated with the oxygen to metal charge transfer processes. An additional absorption shoulder appears at around 410 nm, but since the compound is only weakly colored it is very weak (ε = 120 M–1 cm–1; see inset in ) and can be only barely observed in almost saturated solutions (c = (2.6–5.2) × 10–4 M; A = 0.15). Therefore, the stability tests were performed on rather diluted solution of KLT-1 with concentration of 8.0 × 10–6 M. Time-dependent measurements showed that the spectrum of the solution remains unchanged for at least 1 day (Figure S8) that indicates the stability of polyanions 1 in this medium and, thus, allows for cyclic voltammetry measurements on the polyanions.

Solution Studies

Solution studies (UV-vis spectroscopy and cyclic voltammetry) have been performed for the compound KLT-1 comprising a discrete cluster structure.

UV-vis Measurements

The UV-vis spectrum of KLT-1 redissolved in 0.66 M LiOAc buffer (pH 5.3) averaged from the solutions with concentrations between 4.0 × 10-6 and 8.0 × 10-6 M exhibits a sharp absorption maximum at 226 nm (ε = 140239 M-1 cm-1) and a shoulder at 275 nm (ε = 76684 M-1 cm-1) in the UV range () which are associated with the oxygen to metal charge transfer processes. An additional absorption shoulder appears at around 410 nm, but since the compound is only weakly colored it is very weak (ε = 120 M-1 cm-1; see inset in ) and can be only barely observed in almost saturated solutions (c = (2.6-5.2) × 10-4 M; A = 0.15). Therefore, the stability tests were performed on rather diluted solution of KLT-1 with concentration of 8.0 × 10-6 M. Time-dependent measurements showed that the spectrum of the solution remains unchanged for at least 1 day (Figure S8) that indicates the stability of polyanions 1 in this medium and, thus, allows for cyclic voltammetry measurements on the polyanions.

elements.content: The typical voltammogram of KLT-1 solutions in 0.66 M LiOAc buffer (pH 5.3) exhibits four reversible and quasi-reversible redox processes ( and S9). Three of the observed redox couples, centered at −0.53 V (ΔE = 0.04 V at 50 mV/s), −0.66 V (ΔE = 0.03 V at 50 mV/s), and −0.85 V (ΔE = 0.06 V at 50 mV/s) vs an Ag/AgCl reference electrode, correspond to the WVI ↔ WV transitions; while the fourth one with E 1/2 = +0.56 V (vs. Ag/AgCl) reflects oxidation of CeIII in 1 to CeIV, which appears to be quasi-reversible (ΔE = 0.08 V at 50 mV/s). The CeIII/CeIV process-associated redox wave could be only observed clearly after addition of a small amount of tetramethyl­ammonium chloride (TMACl, ∼3 mg mL–1) to the initial 0.5 mM solution of KLT-1 in 0.66 M LiOAc (pH 5.3) as otherwise it was too broad due to uncompensated solution resistance. At that, the redox waves related to POT were clearly seen in the original solution. The peaks currents for all the reduction and oxidation processes are proportional to the square root of the scan rate (Figures S10–S13), which indicates diffusion-controlled electrode reactions. Assuming the two-electron process for the CeIII oxidation (one-electron oxidation for the every of the two CeIII ions per polyanion 1) and using the Randles-Sevcik equation, the diffusion coefficient D for 1 was estimated to be around 9.04 × 10–7 cm2 s–1, which compares well to the values reported for other POTs.
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemical Studies

The typical voltammogram of KLT-1 solutions in 0.66 M LiOAc buffer (pH 5.3) exhibits four reversible and quasi-reversible redox processes ( and S9). Three of the observed redox couples, centered at -0.53 V (ΔE = 0.04 V at 50 mV/s), -0.66 V (ΔE = 0.03 V at 50 mV/s), and -0.85 V (ΔE = 0.06 V at 50 mV/s) vs an Ag/AgCl reference electrode, correspond to the WVI ↔ WV transitions; while the fourth one with E 1/2 = +0.56 V (vs. Ag/AgCl) reflects oxidation of CeIII in 1 to CeIV, which appears to be quasi-reversible (ΔE = 0.08 V at 50 mV/s). The CeIII/CeIV process-associated redox wave could be only observed clearly after addition of a small amount of tetramethylammonium chloride (TMACl, ~3 mg mL-1) to the initial 0.5 mM solution of KLT-1 in 0.66 M LiOAc (pH 5.3) as otherwise it was too broad due to uncompensated solution resistance. At that, the redox waves related to POT were clearly seen in the original solution. The peaks currents for all the reduction and oxidation processes are proportional to the square root of the scan rate (Figures S10-S13), which indicates diffusion-controlled electrode reactions. Assuming the two-electron process for the CeIII oxidation (one-electron oxidation for the every of the two CeIII ions per polyanion 1) and using the Randles-Sevcik equation, the diffusion coefficient D for 1 was estimated to be around 9.04 × 10-7 cm2 s-1, which compares well to the values reported for other POTs.

elements.content: To determine the diamagnetic susceptibility contribution of the [α2-P2W17O61]10– building block, the susceptibility of its corresponding diamagnetic potassium salt was determined, since standard methods (e.g. based on tabulated increments) usually overestimate the diamagnetism of larger POTs due to their intrinsic temperature-independent paramagnetism. The experimental dc susceptibility data of KLT-1, KNT-3, and LT-4 were corrected accordingly, and are shown as χm T vs T plots and M m vs B plots in . At 290 K and 0.1 T, the χm T values of KLT-1 and LT-4 (both incorporating two CeIII centers) are 1.34 and 1.48 cm3 K/mol, respectively, while the value of KNT-3 (four CeIII centers) is 2.65 cm3 K/mol. These values fall within the expected ranges for two (1.32–1.56 cm3 K/mol) or four (2.65–3.13 cm3 K/mol) noninteracting CeIII centers. Upon cooling, the χm T values of all compounds continuously decrease reaching 0.72 (KLT-1), 0.75 (LT-4), and 1.57 cm3 K/mol (KNT-3), respectively, at 2.0 K. This behavior is due to thermal depopulation of the m J energy substates of the 2J + 1 ground term. They are split and mixed due to the single-ion effects (interelectron repulsion, ligand field, and spin–orbit coupling) yielding magnetically anisotropic centers. In addition, very weak exchange interactions might be present (most likely antiferromagnetic), particularly for KNT-3. As a good approximation, the molar magnetizations M m of KLT-1 and LT-4 as a function of the applied magnetic field B are identical at 2.0 K. They both slowly increase showing a nonlinear curve with a value of 1.8 N A μB at 5.0 T without being saturated. KNT-3 displays similar behavior: M m continuously increases reaching 3.5 N A μB at 5.0 T without being saturated. The expected saturation values are about 4.3 N A μB (= 2g J JN AμB) for two and 8.6 N A μB for four noninteracting CeIII centers. The measured values are about half the expected values, which is quite common for most of noninteracting lanthanide centers due to the measurement of powder samples, i.e., the mean values of statistically oriented and anisotropic centers. Since we do not detect characteristic deviations from the expectations for noninteracting centers, we cannot further elaborate on the possibility of exchange interactions than given above.

They are split and mixed due to the single-ion effects (interelectron repulsion, ligand field, and spin-orbit coupling) yielding magnetically anisotropic centers. In addition, very weak exchange interactions might be present (most likely antiferromagnetic), particularly for KNT-3. elements.content: In summary, the direct reactions of multilacunary Wells-Dawson-type polyoxotungstates {P2W12} and {P2W15} with cerium­(III) chloride in different aqueous buffer solutions yield several novel architectures based on CeIII-functionalized monolacunary Wells-Dawson-type {α2-P2W17} phosphotungstates. The resulting compounds are based on both discrete polyanions [{Ce­(H2O)3(α2-P2W17O61)}2]14– (1) as well as coordination polymers with 1D {[Ce­(H2O)7]2[{Ce­(H2O) x ­(CH3COO)­(α2-P2W17O61)}2]} n (2, 3) and 2D {[Ce­(H2O)7]­[Ce­(H2O)4(α2-P2W17O61)]} n (4) structures. Polyanion 1 represents the first example of a 2:2 dimer with a “cap-to-belt” structure for an earlier lanthanide (La, Ce, Pr), not decorated by any further external LnIII ions. Its electrochemical behavior associated with the reversible redox transitions of both WVI and CeIII centers suggests that 1 might potentially serve as an attractive electrocatalyst for various redox reactions. Compounds KNT-2 and NT-3 are based on [{Ce­(H2O) x (CH3COO)­(α2-P2W17O61)}2]14– polyanions and constitute the only second known example of acetate-bridged {α2-LnP2W17} dimers, which in 2 and 3 are further linked into infinite chains via additional CeIII ions. In LT-4 monomeric 1:1 {α2-CeP2W17} units are bridged by oxo ligands and external CeIII centers into 2D nets with a thus-far unprecedented structure. Thus, our study demonstrates that despite its seeming simplicity, the LnIII/{α2-P2W17} structural system offers an impressive flexibility, allowing for isolation of numerous structures of various nuclearities, dimensionalities, and topologies; all triggered by small modifications of the reaction conditions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, the direct reactions of multilacunary Wells-Dawson-type polyoxotungstates {P2W12} and {P2W15} with cerium(III) chloride in different aqueous buffer solutions yield several novel architectures based on CeIII-functionalized monolacunary Wells-Dawson-type {α2-P2W17} phosphotungstates. The resulting compounds are based on both discrete polyanions [{Ce(H2O)3(α2-P2W17O61)}2]14- (1) as well as coordination polymers with 1D {[Ce(H2O)7]2[{Ce(H2O) x (CH3COO)(α2-P2W17O61)}2]} n  (2, 3) and 2D {[Ce(H2O)7][Ce(H2O)4(α2-P2W17O61)]} n  (4) structures. Polyanion 1 represents the first example of a 2:2 dimer with a "cap-to-belt" structure for an earlier lanthanide (La, Ce, Pr), not decorated by any further external LnIII ions. Its electrochemical behavior associated with the reversible redox transitions of both WVI and CeIII centers suggests that 1 might potentially serve as an attractive electrocatalyst for various redox reactions. Compounds KNT-2 and NT-3 are based on [{Ce(H2O) x (CH3COO)(α2-P2W17O61)}2]14- polyanions and constitute the only second known example of acetate-bridged {α2-LnP2W17} dimers, which in 2 and 3 are further linked into infinite chains via additional CeIII ions. In LT-4 monomeric 1:1 {α2-CeP2W17} units are bridged by oxo ligands and external CeIII centers into 2D nets with a thus-far unprecedented structure. Thus, our study demonstrates that despite its seeming simplicity, the LnIII/{α2-P2W17} structural system offers an impressive flexibility, allowing for isolation of numerous structures of various nuclearities, dimensionalities, and topologies; all triggered by small modifications of the reaction conditions.
